thread.title: SMSFs lose $40bn in six months as Australian equities underperform
thread.title_full: SMSFs lose $40bn in six months as Australian equities underperform | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: Michael Roddan
title: SMSFs lose $40bn in six months as Australian equities underperform
text:
AUSTRALIAN self-managed super funds are on track to lose $40 billion over the past six months, as they post their biggest losses in four years, according to research from Credit Suisse.
“Selfie” funds lost $19 billion over the three months to June and are set to lose a further $21 billion over the September quarter, which would be the largest losses for self-managed funds since 2011, the investment bank says in a report.
There are more than one million SMSF members in Australia that manage around 557,000 funds with nearly $600 billion of assets under management, according to figures from the tax office.
SMSFs now hold around 29 per cent of Australian superannuation assets, down from 30 per cent this time last year, as they have lost “supermarket share” almost exclusively to industry funds, Credit Suisse analyst Hasan Tevfik said.
“We believe much of the reason why selfies are losing superannuation market share is because of their relatively poor recent performance,” Mr Tevfik said.
Mr Tevfik said selfie owners were committed to buying Australian equities, which have underperformed compared to their global peers.
SMSFs had 40 per cent of their assets held in Australian equities and “little” in international equities as of June last year, compared to industry funds that held 24 per cent in local equities and 26 per cent in global stocks.
“Over the subsequent 12 months, Aussie equities returned 6 per cent while global stocks piled on a staggering 23 per cent in Australian dollar,” Mr Tevfik said. “Selfies’ commitment to Aussie equities is now being questioned.”
This means that the average SMSF member would have endured a drawdown of about $18,000 in the June quarter and a further $20,000 in the September quarter.
Local stocks hold particular attraction for investors because of the high yield in a low interest rate environment. The current gross dividend yield on Australian equities is 7.5 per cent — three times the deposit rate.
Credit Suisse estimates that selfies were paid $12 billion in dividends by Australian companies in the last financial year, and expects a similar amount for the coming fiscal period.
“Aussie equities are a brightly shining beacon of yield against an investment landscape barren of income generating assets,” Mr Tevfik said.
“Selfies buy what they know and ATO data suggests they have a clear domestic bias,” he said.
 SMSFs lose $40bn in six months
